eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The Amf with ID [AmfId] no longer exists, so the AMF cannot clear its parent config info.

details.customerDescription: Could not clear parent config info for amf id [AmfId] - it no longer exists
details.formatString: Could not clear parent config info for amf id 0x%llx - it no longer exists

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is displayed to the user as SmsDevice/4. The Amf has added the partition [amf_name].[index] to the list of partitions. It begins at block # [partStart] and is [partSize] blocks long.

details.customerDescription: Added partition [amf_name].[index], offset [partStart], size [partSize]
details.formatString: Added partition %s.%lu, offset %llu, size %llu

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is displayed to the user as SmsDevice/6. The Amf has removed the partition [amf_name].[part_index] from the list of partitions. This partition began at block # [part_offset] and was [part_size] blocks long.

details.customerDescription: Removed partition [amf_name].[part_index], offset [part_offset], size [part_size]
details.formatString: Removed partition %s.%lu, offset %llu, size %llu

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The partition [amf_name].[part_index] cannot be removed, because it is currently exported to hosts for I/O.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Unexport partitions before attempting to delete them.

details.customerDescription: failed to lock virtual volume %s.%lu
details.internalDescription: A request to delete a partition failed because that partition is currently exported.
details.formatString: failed to lock virtual volume %s.%lu

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is displayed to the user as SmsDevice/2. The amf [amf_name] has been expanded by adding a new child node, [child_amf_name], into its child slot number [slot_num], and the new capacity is [new_capacity].

details.customerDescription: A request to expand a virtual-volume or device succeeded.
details.formatString: Expanded amf \"%s\": added amf \"%s\" into slot %lu, new raid-c capacity %\"FS64u\" bytes

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: As of March 2005, the user has no way of doing this through SMS. But the tower command "amf shrink" will remove the highest-numbered child of a RAID-C.

details.customerDescription: Successfully shrank amf \"%s\"
details.internalDescription: The device has been reduced in size by removing the child node from its highest-numbered child slot.
details.formatString: Successfully shrank amf \"%s\"

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The number of mirrors of the raid 1 amf [amf_name] has been increased by one, by adding a child amf, [child_amf_name], into the child slot number [slot].

details.customerDescription: Added mirror to amf \"%s\": added amf \"%s\" into slot %lu
details.internalDescription: A new mirror has been added to increase the number of copies (redundancy).
details.formatString: Added mirror to amf \"%s\": added amf \"%s\" into slot %lu

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: Issued on the master amg director only.

details.customerDescription: Successfully removed mirror %lu of amf \"%s\"
details.internalDescription: One redundant copy of the data has been removed.
details.formatString: Successfully removed mirror %lu of amf \"%s\"

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is displayed to the user as SmsDevice/5. Partition [amf_name].[partIdx] has been expanded from size [old_part_size] to size [part_size]. The partition's offset is [part_offset].

details.arguments: amf_name partIdx part_offset old_part_size part_offset part_size
details.customerDescription: Expanded partition %s.%lu from offset %llu size %llu to offset %llu size %llu
details.formatString: Expanded partition %s.%lu from offset %llu size %llu to offset %llu size %llu

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The amf [amf_name] cannot be removed or expanded, because it is currently exported to hosts for I/O.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Unexport the virtual volume of the device before modifying the device.

details.customerDescription: failed to lock device or storage volume \"%s\":" " virtual volume %s is in use
details.internalDescription: A device cannot be deleted, expanded or copied to or from when its virtual volume is exported.
details.formatString: failed to lock device or storage volume \"%s\":" " virtual volume %s is in use

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is displayed to the user as SmsDevice/3. The amf named [amf_name] has been removed.

details.customerDescription: Removed RG \"%s\"
details.formatString: Removed RG \"%s\"

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is displayed to the user as SmsDevice/1. The Amf [amf_name] has been created. It is of type [amf_type] (allowed values: raid0, raid1, raidc).

details.customerDescription: created amf \"%s\" type: %s
details.formatString: created amf \"%s\" type: %s

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The storage volume with logical unit id [oldStorageVolumeLuid] has been logically replaced in its amf tree with the storage volume with logical unit id [newStorageVolumeLuid].
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Check the status of the storage volumes. Replace any storage volumes that failed.

details.customerDescription: replacing storage volume %s with storage volume %s
details.internalDescription: The original storage volume is no longer available. The auto-replace policy was enabled for this storage volume so it is being replaced by another storage volume from the same spare pool.
details.formatString: replacing storage volume %s with storage volume %s

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The attempt to start the raid 1 startup timer for the raid 1 amf [amf_name] failed. This means that the given raid 1 will most likely remain unavailable for I/O until the director is rebooted.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: A system reset may restore normal operation. Do not attempt this if there is any active I/O. If the problem persists, contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: raid 1 \"%s\": could not start timer
details.internalDescription: During initialization an unexpected software error occurred. The reported device is not available.
details.formatString: raid 1 \"%s\": could not start timer

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The raid 1 [amf_name] was updating (rebuilding) one of its child nodes (the one in the [amf_slot]th slot, named [child_name]. Then an [opName] (allowed values: read, write, sector re-map, log read, log write) operation failed, which caused it to abandon the rebuild. The type of the rebuild is specified by the string in [type], and is either "full", "redo log" or "undo log".
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Check the status of storage volumes under Device Configuration. If any storage volumes are unreachable, check all of the physical connections to the enclosure containing those storage volumes. If problem persists, contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: raid 1 rebuild: %s: child node %lu (%s) rebuild abandoned: %s failed (%s rebuild)
details.internalDescription: An error occurred during the rebuild of the given storage volume or device in the reported device. The rebuild was abandoned.
details.formatString: raid 1 rebuild: %s: child node %lu (%s) rebuild abandoned: %s failed (%s rebuild)

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: An amf will not start rebuilding because the capacities of one or more of the storage volumes involved are so small that certain assumptions are no longer valid. In particular, the topology of the amf means that the rebuild I/Os will be of size [blockCount] blocks, which is smaller than the minimum allowed value of [minBlockCount]. This event will only happen with testing, when using artificially small simulated storage volumes. It will never happen with real storage volumes.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Ensure storage volumes in spare pools are the same size or larger than storage volumes in the devices which may require replacement.

details.customerDescription: block count %lu is less than minimum allowed (%u): rebuild will not be started
details.internalDescription: The capacity of a storage volume chosen for a rebuild is too small so the rebuild cannot proceed.
details.formatString: block count %lu is less than minimum allowed (%u): rebuild will not be started

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is a notice that a RAID1 rebuild has begun on the child nodes of [amf_name]. I.e., one or more of the child nodes of [amf_name] are out-of-date, and the process of rebuilding those child nodes is now starting. The type of the rebuild is specified by the string in [type], and is either "full" or "log".
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: No user action is required.

details.customerDescription: raid 1 rebuild: %s: started rebuilding child node(s) (%s rebuild)
details.internalDescription: One or more child devices are out-of-date and are being rebuilt. This process may impact on performance if it is a very large rebuild.
details.formatString: raid 1 rebuild: %s: started rebuilding child node(s) (%s rebuild)

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is a notice that the RAID1 amf [amf_name] is starting a rebuild of one of its child nodes: the [child_index]th one, which has the name [child_name]. The type of the rebuild is specified by the string in [type], and is either "full", "redo log" or "undo log". Note that this event, with rebuild type "undo log", indicates tossing of user data. So it should really get a higher severity.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: No user action is required.

details.customerDescription: raid 1 rebuild: %s: child node %lu (%s) rebuild started (%s rebuild)
details.internalDescription: One or more child devices are out-of-date and are being rebuilt. This process may impact on performance if it is a very large rebuild.
details.formatString: raid 1 rebuild: %s: child node %lu (%s) rebuild started (%s rebuild)

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is a notice that the RAID1 amf [amf_name] has successfully completed a rebuild of one of its child nodes: the [child_index]th one, which has the name [child_name]. The type of the rebuild is specified by the string in [type], and is either "full", "redo log" or "undo log".
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: No user action is required.

details.customerDescription: raid 1 rebuild: %s: child node %lu (%s) rebuild successfully completed (%s rebuild)
details.internalDescription: The RAID 1 successfully completed a rebuild of one of its child devices.
details.formatString: raid 1 rebuild: %s: child node %lu (%s) rebuild successfully completed (%s rebuild)

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is a notice that a RAID1 rebuild of the child nodes of [amf_name] has completed. The type of the rebuild is specified by the string in [type], and is either "full" or "log".
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: No user action is required.

details.customerDescription: raid 1 rebuild: %s: finished rebuilding child node(s) (%s rebuild)
details.formatString: raid 1 rebuild: %s: finished rebuilding child node(s) (%s rebuild)

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is a warning that a rebuild of the child nodes of the RAID 1 node [amf_name] will not take place, because it is impossible to do I/O to [amf_name]. Reasons for this include: [amf_name] is dead, unreachable, out-of-date, hasn't come online yet, or has been marked unusable because of an unresolved conflict in on-disk configuration information.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Check the log for earlier events reporting problems with that device and follow any recommended action. Check the log for later events to determine if the rebuild succeeded on another director or if it was abandoned.

details.customerDescription: refusing rebuild of device \"%s\": parent is not I
details.internalDescription: The system assigned the rebuild of a storage volume to a director that cannot perform I/O on the device. The rebuild will be assigned to another director. If no directors can perform the rebuild, an error will be generated.
details.formatString: refusing rebuild of device \"%s\": parent is not I

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is a warning that a rebuild of the child nodes of the RAID 1 node [amf_name] will not take place, because none of them can be rebuilt. Usually this occurs because a child node is reachable on one director but not another. This means that one director notices the necessity of a rebuild, but the rebuild is assigned to the director that is unable to reach the out-of-date child node. That director refuses the rebuild and prints this event message. The AMG component will retry the rebuild up to a certain maximum number of tries on successive directors. If no director is able to do a rebuild, the AMG logs an event message.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: No user action is required.

details.customerDescription: refusing rebuild of device \"%s\": no rebuildable child node
details.internalDescription: The system assigned the rebuild of a storage volume to a director that cannot perform the operation. The rebuild will be assigned to another director. If no directors can perform the rebuild, an error is generated.
details.formatString: refusing rebuild of device \"%s\": no rebuildable child node

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: A RAID1 rebuild of the child nodes of [amf_name] could not be started because memory for it could not be allocated. The type of the rebuild is specified by the string in [type], and is either "full" or "log".
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Check if the rebuild has started on a different director. If it has, no other action is necessary. If it does not start anywhere else, contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: could not allocate memory to rebuild child nodes of RAID 1 \"%s\" (%s rebuild)
details.internalDescription: The system assigned the rebuild of a storage volume to a director that cannot perform the operation. The rebuild will be assigned to another director. If no directors can perform the rebuild, an error is generated.
details.formatString: could not allocate memory to rebuild child nodes of RAID 1 \"%s\" (%s rebuild)

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: A RAID1 rebuild of [amf_name] could not be started because the rebuild thread for it could not be started. The type of the rebuild is specified by the string in [type], and is either "full" or "log".
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Check if the rebuild is started on a different director. If it has, no other action is necessary. If it does not start anywhere else, contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: could not start rebuild thread for RAID 1 \"%s\" (%s rebuild)
details.internalDescription: The system assigned the rebuild of a storage volume to a director that cannot perform the operation. The rebuild will be assigned to another director. If no directors can perform the rebuild, an error is generated.
details.formatString: could not start rebuild thread for RAID 1 \"%s\" (%s rebuild)

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: While reading the on-disk configuration information for a storage volume with logical unit id [storageVolume_id] and amf id [amf_id], the AMF layer noticed that the configuration information did not contain a version number, so it is acting as if it found a version number of zero. The storage volume most likely had its configuration information written by an older version of the director firmware, which didn't identify the version of that information.

details.customerDescription: version for storage volume id %s (amf id 0x%llx) not found - using zero (0)
details.internalDescription: Configuration data found on the reported storage volume is of an older version than the system version. Storage volume configuration data was updated.
details.formatString: version for storage volume id %s (amf id 0x%llx) not found - using zero (0)

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The storage volume amf [amf_name] was in use, and during that time, one or more I/Os failed with a recommendation from the DISK layer that the sectors be re-mapped. Now that storage volume is becoming spare, and the AMF layer is discarding the list of these re-map regions. This event indicates that the region of blocks inclusively between [startBlock] and [endBlock] is being discarded.

details.customerDescription: storage volume \"%s\" becoming spare, discarding re-map region [%lu, %lu]
details.internalDescription: After the system updates its on-disk configuration data, the storage volume is returned to a spare pool.
details.formatString: storage volume \"%s\" becoming spare, discarding re-map region [%lu, %lu]

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The AMF layer has resolved a version conflict of on-disk configuration information. The child node [child_name] was previously the child of the parent [parent_name], which has a configuration version number of [parent_version]. Now [child_name] has been changed to be a child of the parent [new_parent_name], which has a configuration version number of [new_parent_version].

details.customerDescription: child \"%s\" parent \"%s\" ver %llu replaced with parent \"%s\" ver %llu
details.internalDescription: The system resolved a version conflict of on-disk configuration information.
details.formatString: child \"%s\" parent \"%s\" ver %llu replaced with parent \"%s\" ver %llu

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: Note: the parameter list line violates the line width limit. This was done to appease the parser used to put these events in the SMS database. The AMF layer has resolved a version conflict of on-disk configuration information. The parent node named [parent_name] has a child named [child_name] in slot number [childSlot], and that child has configuration version [child_version]. The AMF layer is ignoring a node named [other_child_name] with configuration version [other_child_version], that has configuration information that states that it should be in the slot occupied byt [child_name]. In this case, the imposter [other_child_name] was rejected because [other_child_version] is less than [child_version].

details.arguments: parent_name child_name childSlot child_version other_child_name other_child_version
details.customerDescription: parent \"%s\" child \"%s\" slot %lu ver %llu ignoring \"imposter\" child \"%s\" ver %llu
details.internalDescription: The system resolved a version conflict of on-disk configuration information.
details.formatString: parent \"%s\" child \"%s\" slot %lu ver %llu ignoring \"imposter\" child \"%s\" ver %llu

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The AMF layer has resolved a version conflict of on-disk configuration information. The parent node named [parent_name] had a child node named [child_name] in slot number [childSlot], which a configuration version of [child_version]. The AMF layer has removed that child and replaced it with the node named [new_child_name], which has configuration version [new_child_version].

details.arguments: parent_name child_name childSlot child_version new_child_name new_child_version
details.customerDescription: parent \"%s\" replacing \"imposter\" child \"%s\" slot %lu ver %llu with child \"%s\" ver %llu
details.internalDescription: The system resolved a version conflict of on-disk configuration information.
details.formatString: parent \"%s\" replacing \"imposter\" child \"%s\" slot %lu ver %llu with child \"%s\" ver %llu

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The on-disk configuration information for a parent node always contains a list of child nodes, plus version numbers and flag values for the child nodes. This is used for resolving conflicts in on-disk configuration information on different storage volumes. In this case, the on-disk configuration information for the amf node is missing the child version number for the child that should be that slot.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: The cluster found a previous version of device configuration data. This will not affect the use of the device.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Check the status of the devices to determine which device is not available. Contact EMC Customer Support.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Check the status of the devices to determine which device is not available. Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: The cluster found a previous version of device configuration data.
details.internalDescription: The cluster found a previous version of device configuration data.
details.formatString: Device \"%s\": slot %lu: missing act_childVersion tag

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The on-disk configuration information for a parent node always contains a list of child nodes, plus version numbers and flag values for the child nodes. This is used for resolving conflicts in on-disk configuration information on different storage volumes. In this case, the on-disk configuration information for the amf node named [parent_name] is missing the child flags value for the child that should be in slot number [childSlot].
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Check the status of the devices to determine which device is not available. Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: Device \"%s\": slot %lu: missing act_childFlags tag
details.internalDescription: The system found a previous version of device configuration data. This will not affect the use of the device.
details.formatString: Device \"%s\": slot %lu: missing act_childFlags tag

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: While reading the on-disk configuration information for the amf with id [ID], the AMF layer noticed that the configuration information did not contain a version number, so it is acting as if it found a version number of zero. The amf most likely had its configuration information written by an older version of the director firmware, which didn't identify the version of that information.

details.customerDescription: version for amf id 0x%llx not found - using zero (0)
details.internalDescription: The system found a previous version of device configuration data. This will not affect the use of the device.
details.formatString: version for amf id 0x%llx not found - using zero (0)

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is the same as event amf/34, but it occurs at a different place in the code.

details.internalDescription: The system found a previous version of device configuration data. This will not affect the use of the device.
details.formatString: Device \"%s\": slot %lu: missing act_childVersion tag

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is the same as event amf/35, but it occurs at a different place in the code.

details.internalDescription: The system found a previous version of device configuration data. This will not affect the use of the device.

details.internalDescription: The system found a previous version of device configuration data. This will not affect the use of the device.

details.internalDescription: The system found a previous version of device configuration data. This will not affect the use of the device.

details.internalDescription: The system found a previous version of device configuration data. This will not affect the use of the device.
details.formatString: Device \"%s\": slot %lu: missing act_childVersion tag

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is the same as event amf/35, but it occurs at a different place in the code.

details.customerDescription: Device \"%s\": slot %lu: missing act_childFlags tag
details.internalDescription: The system found a previous version of device configuration data. This will not affect the use of the device.
details.formatString: Device \"%s\": slot %lu: missing act_childFlags tag

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The storage volume amf [amf_name] has gone into a state such that the director would replace it with a spare storage volume and start a rebuild, except that there is no data available to do a rebuild. E.g., [amf_name] is part of a RAID 0, or is part of a RAID 1 that has lost all its other mirrors.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: The storage volume amf [amf_name] has gone into a state such that the director would replace it with a spare storage volume and start a rebuild, except that there is no data available to do a rebuild.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Use the VPlexcli command \"storage-volume resurrect\" to resurrect the storage volume that encountered a problem. If the command fails, re-run the command using the \"--force\" option. If the storage volume is still not resurrected, please contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: not replacing storage volume \"%s\" - no redundant data is available for a rebuild
details.internalDescription: A storage volume failed and cannot be rebuilt. The device that contained that storage volume was lost.
details.formatString: not replacing storage volume \"%s\" - no redundant data is available for a rebuild

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The storage volume amf [amf_name] has gone into a state such that the director would replace it with a spare storage volume and start a rebuild, except that automatic replacement is turned of for [amf_name]. This has got to be at least a warning, maybe
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Ensure that there are storage volumes available for auto-replacement in the spare pool. Enable auto-replace for the affected device. Replace any failed storage volumes as soon as possible.

details.customerDescription: not replacing storage volume \"%s\" - replacement is turned off for this storage volume
details.internalDescription: The device is in a state such that the director would replace it with a spare storage volume and start a rebuild, except that automatic replacement is turned off for the device.
details.formatString: not replacing storage volume \"%s\" - replacement is turned off for this storage volume

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The Amf is marking the storage volume with logical unit id [storageVolumeId] and type [storageVolumeType] (allowed values: spare, in-use) as having the state [deathType] (allowed values: dead, unreachable). The [logPrefix] parameter is a short prefix giving the reason for marking the storage volume dead or unreachable. The allowed values are: "disk event: ", "too many sector re-maps: ", "re-map table full: ", "sector re-map failed: ", "too many queued sector re-maps: ", "write failure: ", "read failure: ", "config write failed: ", "config read failed: " and "". Note that this event can fire and say "in-use" storage volume, for a storage volume that's been marked dead and replaced, and is no longer in any AMF.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Replace any failed storage volumes as soon as possible. If an unreachable storage volume caused the device to become unusable, call EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: storage volume %s: %smarking this %s storage volume %s
details.internalDescription: The reported storage volume has failed or the system can no longer access it. If that storage volume was in-use, the device may have lost redundancy or failed completely.
details.formatString: storage volume %s: %smarking this %s storage volume %s

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The Amf [amf_name] does not have its capacity recorded in the on-disk configuration information. This is because that information was recorded by an older version of the software. As soon as the Amf becomes initialized, the Amf layer will determine its capacity and record it in the on-disk configuration information, so this warning will not be seen again.

details.customerDescription: Device \"%s\": missing act_capacity tag
details.internalDescription: The system found and updated configuration data stored on the storage volumes.
details.formatString: Device \"%s\": missing act_capacity tag

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The Amf [amf_name] did not have its capacity recorded in the on-disk configuration information. It has now become initialized, so the Amf layer is computing its capacity and recording it in the on-disk configuration information.

details.customerDescription: amf %s: computing capacity, persistently storing it
details.formatString: amf %s: computing capacity, persistently storing it

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The AMF layer has received an event of type [eventType] (allowed values: new/returned, lost) for the storage volume with logical unit id [storageVolumeId]. It is ignoring this event, because the storage volume has a capacity of [capacity] bytes, which is smaller than the minimum allowed value of [minCapacity] bytes. This event will only happen with testing, when using artificially small simulated storage volumes. It will never happen with real storage volumes.

details.customerDescription: ignoring %s event for storage volume %s: capacity (%llu) is less than minimum (%u)
details.internalDescription: The system discovered a storage volume with a capacity that is smaller than the minimum allowed. The system will not use this storage volume.
details.formatString: ignoring %s event for storage volume %s: capacity (%llu) is less than minimum (%u)

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The AMF layer has resolved a version conflict of on-disk configuration information. The parent node named [parentName] has configuration version [parentVersion] and has a child named [childName] in slot number [childSlot]. The AMF layer is ignoring a node named [otherChildName] that claims to fit into [childSlot] of version [otherParentVersion] of [parentName]. In this case, the imposter [otherChildName] was rejected because [otherParentVersion] is less than [parentVersion]..

details.arguments: parentName parentVersion childName childSlot otherChildName otherParentVersion
details.customerDescription: parent \"%s\" ver %llu child \"%s\" slot %lu ignoring \"imposter\" child \"%s\" with parent ver %llu
details.internalDescription: The system resolved a version conflict of on-disk configuration information.
details.formatString: parent \"%s\" ver %llu child \"%s\" slot %lu ignoring \"imposter\" child \"%s\" with parent ver %llu

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The on-disk configuration information for the amf node [amf_name] could not be read. Because of this, [amf_name] has been marked unusable.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: couldn't read parent config for device or storage volume \"%s\"
details.internalDescription: The system could not read the on-disk configuration information for the reported device. This device cannot be used.
details.formatString: couldn't read parent config for device or storage volume \"%s\"

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: During the process of building amf trees from on-disk configuration information, the AMF layer noticed inconsistencies. The parent amf node has an invalid node type. Because of this, the parent and child node that was trying to attach to it have been marked unusable.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: The on-disk configuration information for the reported device is inconsistent, due to the parent having an invalid type. This inconsistency cannot be resolved and the device is not available.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Check the status of the devices to determine which device is not available.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Check the status of the devices to determine which device is not available. Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: A parent device has an invalid type.
details.internalDescription: A parent device has an invalid type.
details.formatString: parent device \"%s\" invalid type %u

An amf node was trying to become the child of another node, at which point it was noticed that another child of the proposed parent had an amf id that differs from the expected sibling amf id specified in the on-disk configuration for the child's parent. eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: During the process of building amf trees from on-disk configuration information, the AMF layer noticed inconsistencies. An amf node was trying to become a child of another node, at which point it was noticed that another child of the proposed parent had a configuration version which was lower than the one specified in the child's on-disk configuration. Ordinarily, we would delete the proposed and re-create it based on the child's on-disk configuration, but it is too late to do so, because the proposed parent is already initialized. Because of this, the child, the sibling and the propsed parent have all been marked unusable.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: The on-disk configuration information for the reported device is inconsistent. This inconsistency cannot be resolved and the device is not available.

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: During the process of building amf trees from on-disk configuration information, the AMF layer noticed inconsistencies. An amf node was trying to become a child of a parent node when it was noticed that the parent's configuration version was lower than the parent version specified in the child's on-disk configuration. Ordinarily, we would delete the parent and re-create it based on the child's on-disk configuration, but it is too late to do so, because the parent is already initialized. Because of this, the child and parent have been marked unusable.

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: During the process of building amf trees from on-disk configuration information, the AMF layer noticed inconsistencies. An amf node was trying to become the child of a parent, in the given slot. At this point it was noticed that there already is a child in that slot, and its configuration version is less than the configuration version of the proposed child. Ordinarily, we would remove the existing child and put the new child in its place, but it is too late to do so, because the parent is already initialized. Because of this, the new child, the existing child and parent have all been marked unusable.

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: During the process of building amf trees from on-disk configuration information, the AMF layer noticed inconsistencies. The AMF layer has just created a node from the configuration information in one of its child nodes. At this point, it was noticed that a node indicated in the configuration as another child of the parent (supposedly to be in another slot of the parent) is in fact a spare storage volume. Because of this, the parent and the child from which the parent was created will both be marked unusable. The other child, however, will not.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: The on-disk configuration information for the reported device is inconsistent. This inconsistency cannot be resolved and the device is not available.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Check the status of the devices to determine which device is not available.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Check the status of the devices to determine which device is not available. Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: Proposed child is a spare storage volume.
details.internalDescription: Proposed child is a spare storage volume.
details.formatString: Device \"%s\": proposed child %lu (\"%s\") is a spare storage volume

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The system cannot access the reported storage volume. There is no mirror and the device containing that storage volume can not be accessed.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: The storage volume has become unreachable.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: The cluster lost access to the reported storage volume. The device is still accessible but redundancy was lost. Ensure that back-end cables are connected and switches and back-end disks are powered and correctly configured.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: The cluster lost access to the reported storage volume. The device is still accessible but redundancy was lost. Ensure that back-end cables are connected and switches and back-end disks are powered and correctly configured..

details.customerDescription: Storage volume has become unreachable and no mirror exists.
details.internalDescription: Storage volume has become unreachable and no mirror exists.
details.formatString: storage volume %s: lost access to storage volume, no mirror exists

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The storage volume has died, and there is no mirror of the storage volume.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: The storage volume has failed, and there is no mirror of the storage volume.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: The storage-volume will automatically be resurrected once the underlying condition is resolved. Investigate the underlying condition on the BE: 1] Verify the array's BE disk health and LUN masking. 2] Check the array configuration and the physical connections between (a) the VPLEX BE Port and the backend switch and (b) backend switch and the array. 3] Try cleaning or replacing cable(s) or SFP(s) in the path to the storage volume.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: The storage-volume will automatically be resurrected once the underlying condition is resolved. Investigate the underlying condition on the BE: 1] Verify the array's BE disk health and LUN masking. 2] Check array configuration and the physical connections between (a) the VPLEX BE Port and the backend switch and (b) backend switch and the array. 3] Try cleaning or replacing cable(s) or SFP(s) in the path to the storage volume. If the issue persists contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: A storage volume failed and no mirror exists.
details.internalDescription: A storage volume with no redundancy failed.
details.formatString: storage volume %s: storage volume died, no mirror exists

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The system lost access to the reported storage volume. The device is still accessible but redundancy was lost.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: The system lost access to the reported storage volume. The device is still accessible but redundancy was lost.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: The cluster lost access to the reported storage volume. The device is still accessible but redundancy was lost. Ensure that back-end cables are connected and switches and back-end disks are powered and correctly configured.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: The cluster lost access to the reported storage volume. The device is still accessible but redundancy was lost. Ensure that back-end cables are connected and switches and back-end disks are powered and correctly configured.

details.customerDescription: Lost access to a storage volume, only one mirror remains.
details.internalDescription: The system lost access to the reported storage volume. The device is still accessible but redundancy was lost.
details.formatString: storage volume %s: lost access to storage volume, only one mirror remains

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The storage volume with logical unit id [storageVolumeId] has died, and there is only one mirror of the storage volume. It would be nice to have a different severity (ERR/CRIT), if there are no available spares to replace the failed storage volume. Fixing JBOD events is low priority today.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Replace failed storage volumes immediately.

details.customerDescription: storage volume %s: storage volume died, only one mirror remains
details.internalDescription: The reported storage volume failed and is no longer used by the system.The device is still accessible but redundancy was lost.
details.formatString: storage volume %s: storage volume died, only one mirror remains

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The storage volume with logical unit id [storageVolumeId] has become unreachable, and there are two or more mirrors of the storage volume.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Check the power for the enclosure that houses the storage volume and verify that the disk is seated correctly. If the problem persists, contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: storage volume %s: lost access to storage volume, two or more mirrors remain
details.internalDescription: The system lost access to the reported storage volume. The device is still accessible but some redundancy was lost.
details.formatString: storage volume %s: lost access to storage volume, two or more mirrors remain

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The storage volume with logical unit id [storageVolumeId] has died, and there are two or more mirrors of the storage volume.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Replace failed storage volumes immediately.

details.customerDescription: storage volume %s: storage volume died, two or more mirrors remain
details.internalDescription: The reported storage volume failed and is not used by the system The device is still accessible but some redundancy was lost.
details.formatString: storage volume %s: storage volume died, two or more mirrors remain

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The raid 1 [amfName] was rebuilding all its child nodes. The child node in the [childIdx]th slot, named [childName], was found to be out-of-date, but it cannot be rebuilt because it is dead or unreachable.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Check physical connections to the JBOD containing the problem disk, replace any failed storage volumes, and call EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: raid 1 rebuild: %s: child node %lu (%s) rebuild skipped - child is dead or unreachable
details.internalDescription: The system was trying to rebuild a device, possibly to build a clone, but the target storage volume is either dead or unreachable.
details.formatString: raid 1 rebuild: %s: child node %lu (%s) rebuild skipped - child is dead or unreachable

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The Amf component detected that two different amf nodes have the same amf name. The Amf component renamed the second amf node to prevent a conflict. This occurs because of either (1) a conflict in configuration information that cannot be resolved without manual intervention, or (2) a conflict that occurred because one amf is cluster-local while the other is visible to all clusters. The renaming does not resolve the conflict, but it makes it possible to manually resolve the conflict.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Two discovered devices reported the same device name. This can occur if configuration changes are made when one or more storage volumes are unreachable, if storage devices from separate VPLEXs with existing devices are merged into one VPLEX or if a device becomes visible to all clusters and happens to have the same name as a cluster-local device on one cluster.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Resolve the conflict by using the "amf rename amf" command.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Manual intervention is required. Contact EMC Customer Support to resolve the conflict.

details.arguments: name amfId amfType amfChildCount amfId2 amfType2 amfChildCount2 name2
details.customerDescription: Name conflict detected, renaming 2nd occurrence.
details.internalDescription: Name conflict detected, renaming 2nd occurrence.
details.formatString: name conflict: \"%s\" id/type/childcount 0x%llx/%s/%lu vs 0x%llx/%s/%lu - renaming 2nd occurrence to \"%s\"

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This message, when it appears, always follows an amf/31 event message. A parent amf named [oldName] with configuration version [oldVer] has been replaced with an amf named [newName] with configuration version [newVer]. The amf [oldName] contained the child [childName] in slot [slot], but [newName] does not. In essence, then, child node [childName] is an "imposter" child: it doesn't really belong in slot number [slot], and isn't in that slot now that [oldName] has been replaced with [newName].

details.arguments: childName oldName oldVer slot newName newVer
details.customerDescription: child \"%s\" is in ousted parent \"%s\" (ver %llu) slot %lu, but not new parent \"%s\" (ver %llu)
details.internalDescription: The system discovered a storage volume with out of date configuration information and has made corrections. This can occur if configuration changes are made when a storage volume is unreachable.
details.formatString: child \"%s\" is in ousted parent \"%s\" (ver %llu) slot %lu, but not new parent \"%s\" (ver %llu)

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: During the process of building amf trees from on-disk configuration information, the AMF layer noticed inconsistencies. The AMF layer has just created the parent node from the configuration information in one of its child nodes. At this point, it was noticed that a node indicated in the configuration as another child of the parent (supposedly to be in a slot of the parent) is in fact a storage volume that has been replaced. Because of this, the parent and the child from which the parent was created will both be marked unusable. The other child is already unusable, as it has been replaced. (Recall that once a storage volume has been logically replaced, it is deemed not worthy for use.)
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Conflicting device configuration information was found on storage volumes. VPLEX cannot determine the correct configuration for the reported device and component. This can occur if configuration changes are made when one or more storage volumes are unreachable.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Manual intervention is required.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Manual intervention is required. Contact EMC Customer Support to resolve the conflict.

details.customerDescription: Proposed child is a replaced storage volume.
details.internalDescription: Proposed child is a replaced storage volume.
details.formatString: Device \"%s\": proposed child %u (\"%s\") is a replaced storage volume

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The storage volume should be marked dead, because there was an i/o error while reading its on-disk configuration information. However, because of that error, the information wasn't read, and we don't know what device the storage volume is part of. Consequently, there isn't enough information for the AMF layer to mark the storage volume dead, and neither can automatic replacement take place.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: The given storage volume has problems that prevent VPLEX from reading data on it.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: If the administrator knows which device the storage volume is part of, and the storage volume is mirrored, it is recommended that he or she manually replace the mirror that the storage volume is part of by using the 'amf removemirror' and 'amf addmirror' commands. Note for Customer Support: Manually determine what device the storage volume is part of, if possible, and restore redundancy using the 'remove mirror' and 'add mirror' functionality.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Determine what is causing the read operations from VPLEX to the storage volume to fail. Possible causes include, but are not limited to media problems, reservation conflicts, and intermittent cabling or switch problems. Once you have fixed the issues that caused the reads to fail: 1. Remove the disk from the masking view (on the back-end array). 2. Run the array rediscover command. 3. Put the disk back into the masking view (on the back-end array). 4. Run the array rediscover command again and check the state of the storage-volume to confirm that it is in the OK state.

details.customerDescription: The storage volume has problems that prevent VPLEX from reading it's data.
details.internalDescription: The storage volume has problems that prevent VPLEX from reading it's data.
details.formatString: storage volume %s: should be marked dead, but can't determine parentage

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The raid 1 named [raid1Name] has been marked initialized on one particular snac (the one from which this event message originates) without all of its child nodes being available. In particular, the child with index [index] and name [childName] is not available. An event message of this form will be produced once for each missing child of the raid 1. (I.e., multiple missing child nodes cause multiple events.) If the child's name is not available, then a string consisting of a single question mark character ("?") will be given in [childName]. The raid 1 is able to run without all of its children, but there may be diminished redundancy. The administrator can fix this problem by making the missing storageVolume(s) available if possible, or adding a child node and removing the defunct one via 'amf addmirror' and 'amf removemirror', respectively.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: The missing storage volumes may have already come online. Check the status of all devices and storage volume enclosures. Once all expected devices are discovered the device can be used without risking a rebuild.

details.customerDescription: raid 1 \"%s\" initialized without child %u (\"%s\")
details.internalDescription: Enough storage volumes in the reported RAID1 have been discovered to allow I/O but not all storage volumes have come online. Writes to that device may result in the missing storage volumes being marked out of date and they will require a rebuild when they do come online.
details.formatString: raid 1 \"%s\" initialized without child %u (\"%s\")

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: During the process of building amf trees from on-disk configuration information, the AMF layer noticed inconsistencies. The storage volume amf node named had previously been assigned a slot number in its parent amf. However, it turns out that the on-disk configuration information for the storage volume amf node states that the slot number really should be different. Because of this, the storage volume amf node and the parent have been marked unusable.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: The on-disk configuration information for the reported device is inconsistent. This inconsistency cannot be resolved and the device is not available.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: Storage volume in wrong slot of parent.
details.internalDescription: Storage volume in wrong slot of parent.
details.formatString: storage volume \"%s\" in slot %u of parent \"%s\", but level 0 config says slot %u

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: During the process of building amf trees from on-disk configuration information, the AMF layer noticed inconsistencies. The amf node had previously been assigned a slot number in its parent amf. However, it turns out that the on-disk configuration information a child of the amf node states that the slot number really should be different. Because of this, the amf node, the parent and child have all been marked unusable.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: The on-disk configuration information for the reported device is inconsistent. This inconsistency cannot be resolved and the device is not available.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.arguments: amfName slot parentName childName childSlot newSlot
details.customerDescription: Child in wrong slot of parent.
details.internalDescription: Child in wrong slot of parent.
details.formatString: child \"%s\" in slot %u of its parent \"%s\", but child %u/\"%s\" config says slot %u

eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: A storage volume should only be resurrected if the user somehow knows that the storage volume is healthy, and was incorrectly marked as dead.

details.customerDescription: storage volume %s resurrected
details.internalDescription: This storage volume was previously marked dead or replaced, and now the dead and/or replaced status of the storage volume has been cleared.
details.formatString: storage volume %s resurrected

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: We are unable to log a failed write, so, without further means of determining what the differences are between the mirrors protected by this logging-volume, we have to mark the mirror where the write failed as out of date.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: The system has lost access to the logging-volume device on which it was maintaining a list of changes to the reported device. The specified mirror of the distributed RAID 1 will be marked out of date and completely rebuilt when possible.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Check the accessibility of the logging-volume component and check the accessibility of the underlying storage-volume of the mirror that is marked out of date. Take corrective action, if necessary, to reconnect the inaccessible storage-volumes.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Check the accessibility of the logging-volume component and check the accessibility of the underlying storage-volume of the mirror that is marked out of date. Take corrective action, if necessary, to reconnect the inaccessible storage-volumes. Contact EMC Customer Support for assistance.

details.customerDescription: Logging failed, mirror will be marked out of date.
details.internalDescription: Logging failed, mirror will be marked out of date.
details.formatString: Logging failed to logging volume %s - mirror \"%s\" of device \"%s\" will be marked out of date.

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: A mini-rebuild, reading from source and writing to destination, failed.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: A mini-rebuild, reading from source and writing to destination has failed.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: Failed mini-rebuild from a device or storage volume.
details.internalDescription: Failed mini-rebuild from a device or storage volume.
details.formatString: failed mini-rebuild from device or storage volume %s to device or storage volume %s reason %u

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: When setting up a new bitmap log for a RAID-1, the tower needs to clear the entire log region. This has failed with the given error code, and thus the bitmap log may be starting out its life with bits set. The log setting should be removed and retried.

details.customerDescription: clear of bitmap log on \"%s\" failed with error code %u
details.formatString: clear of bitmap log on \"%s\" failed with error code %u

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: A "mini-rebuild" is starting. It is reading bits from [logAmfName], and using them to control copying of data from [srcAmfName] to [dstAmfName] while partially rebuilding [raid1Name], which is the parent RAID-1.

details.customerDescription: starting mini-rebuild of \"%s\" based on log \"%s\" from child \"%s\" to \"%s\
details.formatString: starting mini-rebuild of \"%s\" based on log \"%s\" from child \"%s\" to \"%s\

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: A "mini-rebuild", previously started on this director, has now completed for RAID-1 [raid1Name]. It needed to copy over [blockCount] blocks of user data. If all other mini-rebuilds of [raid1Name] have completed, then full I/O on [raid1Name] is released, and "midi-rebuilds" (log-based rebuilds) of it can start.

details.customerDescription: done mini-rebuild of \"%s\" - %u blocks
details.formatString: done mini-rebuild of \"%s\" - %u blocks

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: A "mini-rebuild" of RAID-1 [raid1Name] has been abandoned. This is normally because a director or cluster arrival or departure has occurred, and thus the system needs to re-coordinate its mini-rebuilds.

details.customerDescription: abandoned mini-rebuild of \"%s\" after %u blocks
details.formatString: abandoned mini-rebuild of \"%s\" after %u blocks

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The directors save, in flash memory, a list of the ids of distributed device's which they have just been told have been destroyed by another cluster while this cluster was out of touch. This is to handle an obscure case of badly timed cluster shutdown. If this happens, shutdown the entire cluster and contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: Can't write destroyed Rg list to flash
details.formatString: Can't write destroyed Rg list to flash

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is similar to amf/133, but it is the flash read that has failed. The director will assume there are no distributed devices that it needs to destroy.

details.customerDescription: Can't read destroyedRg list from flash
details.formatString: Can't read destroyedRg list from flash

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The director saves, in flash memory, a list of the ids of distributed devices that it has been told about by another cluster, and that cluster (and possibly others) had declared this cluster as detached. Thus, this cluster needs to check the headers of its local storage volumes for this distributed device to see if they indicate any dirty bitmap logs. But, this director has not yet discovered those storage volumes. So, this list is a persisted reminder to check those on-disk headers when the storage volumes show up. If this flash write fails (the write is only even attempted in an unusual case), then if this entire cluster fails, and reboots in a situation where it learns of the storage volumes locally because other clusters are now gone, then data loss is possible. Contact EMC Customer Support. This event should be extremely unlikely.

details.customerDescription: Can't write missing dist Rg list to flash
details.formatString: Can't write missing dist Rg list to flash

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is the read half of event amf/134, and will result in the Amf assuming the list of identified device ids is empty. Since that is the normal case, this event is usually not important. However, it does signal that something is wrong, and as mentioned in amf/134, there is a small risk of data loss.

details.customerDescription: Can't read missingDistRg list from flash
details.formatString: Can't read missingDistRg list from flash

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: An amf storage volume that was intended to be encapsulated based on metadata configuration information has been found to have an existing parent or virtual volume. The metadata header information that was read will be ignored.

details.customerDescription: Encapsulated target storage volume %s has parent or virtual volume, ignoring metadata header information
details.formatString: Encapsulated target storage volume %s has parent or virtual volume, ignoring metadata header information

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: An operation on the storage volume failed because the storage volume's block number needs to be reassigned, and VPLEX cannot do the sector reassignment because storage volume has no mirror. In practice, the operation will almost always be a read, but in very rare situations, the problem could occur for a write.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: VPLEX cannot do the necessary sector reassignment, because the reported storage volume has no mirror.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: Storage volume sector reassign needed.
details.internalDescription: Storage volume sector reassign needed.
details.formatString: storage volume %s block %u: could not %s - sector reassign needed

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: An operation on a virtual volume failed on a block because one of the underlying storage volumes has a block that needs to be reassigned. The cluster cannot do the sector reassignment because the storage volume in question has no mirror. The storage volume and block number in question will be identified in separate amf/137 events. In practice, the operation will almost always be a read, but in very rare situations, the problem could occur for a write.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: An operation on a virtual volume failed on a block because one of the underlying storage volumes has a block that needs to be reassigned. The cluster cannot do the sector reassignment because the storage volume in question has no mirror.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: Volume sector reassign needed.
details.internalDescription: The cluster cannot do the necessary sector reassignment, because an underlying storage volume has no mirror.
details.formatString: volume %s block %llu: could not %s - sector reassign needed

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: A bitmap log was marked invalid, probably because a previous logging attempt failed. The system tried to clear out any stale bits in the log, but failed.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Check all backend cables and switches. Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.arguments: logName startBlock endBlock RAID-name writer-cluster child-slot
details.customerDescription: clear of bitmap log\"%s\"[%llu, %llu) for device %s writer %u" "child %u failed
details.internalDescription: The system was unable to clear internal log data stored on storage volume. In this state a network link failure can result in the entire device being marked out of date and a complete rebuild will be required to recover.
details.formatString: clear of bitmap log\"%s\"[%llu, %llu) for device %s writer %u" "child %u failed

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: We have successfully cleared the given log setting, and it is now ready to be used to logging failed writes.

details.arguments: logName startBlock endBlock RAID-name writer-cluster child-slot
details.customerDescription: Log \"%s\"[%llu, %llu) for device %s writer %u child %u cleared
details.internalDescription: The specified range of pages on the given logging volume have been cleared. The log is once again available for use. The log range is protecting the specified device, when the specified cluster cannot write to the specified child of the device.
details.formatString: Log \"%s\"[%llu, %llu) for device %s writer %u child %u cleared

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: If we are currently rebuilding the mirror, we will roll back the write only as far as the block in question.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: If we are currently rebuilding the mirror, we will roll back the write only as far as the block in question.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: If the mirror is not still showing as out-of-date, it has likely auto-corrected. If it is still marked out-of-date, investigate the backend issues. Once they have been resolved, the rebuild should initiate automatically. This could take time depending on the number of active rebuilds on the system at the time.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: If the mirror is not still showing as out-of-date, it has likely auto-corrected. If it is still marked out-of-date, investigate the backend issues. Once they have been resolved, the rebuild should initiate automatically. This could take time depending on the number of active rebuilds on the system at the time. Contact EMC Customer Support if the condition persists.

details.customerDescription: Mirror has been marked fully out of date.
details.internalDescription: A write failed on the specified mirror of the given device, causing the mirror to be marked out of date.
details.formatString: Mirror \"%s\" of device \"%s\" has been marked fully out of date based on write to block %llu.

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is the first case of the OODEH (out of date escape hole). The dirty log at the detached cluster indicates that there are differences between running mirrors and the mirror that has just come back from being detached. We can't know what those differences are, since they are recorded only in the bitmap logs of the detached cluster. Therefore, we mark mirrors out of date so that we can guarantee that we always serve up the correct data.

details.customerDescription: Detached mirror \"%s\" of device \"%s\" has a dirty log for newly-arrived mirror \"%s\" - marking mirror \"%s\" out of date.
details.internalDescription: Logs from a cluster that is now detached indicate some block differences against a mirror that has just come back into communications. In order to resume operations with data consistency guarateed, we have to mark the specified mirror as fully out of date.
details.formatString: Detached mirror \"%s\" of device \"%s\" has a dirty log for newly-arrived mirror \"%s\" - marking mirror \"%s\" out of date.

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: While the link was down, the local cluster marked the mirrors at some clusters as out of date. Now we've learned that the local cluster was detached by one or more of those clusters, and we have to reverse our earlier decisions and mark the local mirror as out of date.

details.customerDescription: Marking local mirror \"%s\" (slot %u) of device \"%s\" fully out of date after learning that the local cluster has been detached.
details.internalDescription: While the link was down, this cluster marked some other mirrors of the specified distributed device one as out of date. Now that the link has come back and the local cluster has learned that it has been detached, that decision must be reversed.
details.formatString: Marking local mirror \"%s\" (slot %u) of device \"%s\" fully out of date after learning that the local cluster has been detached.

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This situation can arise, for instance, when logs on both sides of a link are unavailable as the link goes down. Without the ability to log, both clusters mark the other as out of date. When the link comes back, both mirrors are out of date, and we have no idea which blocks are the problem ones. We pick one mirror to be up to date so that we can continue accessing the dr1, and lose only some data, as opposed to all of it.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: All of the mirrors of the specified distributed device had been marked out of date. In order to restore access to the device, and to minimize data loss, the specified mirror was marked as up to date.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: Choosing up-to-date mirror for DR1 with no up-to-date mirrors.
details.internalDescription: Choosing up-to-date mirror for DR1 with no up-to-date mirrors.
details.formatString: All mirrors of dr1 \"%s\" have been marked out of date, choosing mirror \"%s\" to be up to date.

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: I/O to a local child of a distributed RAID-1 has failed during a miki-rebuild. The tower is unable to guarantee the coherence of the RAID-1 children, and so does not re-enable I/O to the distributed RAID-1.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: A miki-rebuild has failed because I/O that was part of that rebuild has failed to the local child of a distributed RAID-1. The firmware is unable to guarantee the coherence of the RAID-1, and so does not re-enable I/O to the distributed RAID-1.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: Miki-rebuild I/O failed.
details.internalDescription: Miki-rebuild I/O failed.
details.formatString: Miki-rebuild I/O failed, child \"%s\" parent \"%s\"

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The tower is starting a miki-rebuild of distributed RAID-1 [parentName], reading blocks from the local child and writing them to all children. This was triggered by a director departure at the cluster exporting child [childSlot].

details.customerDescription: starting miki-rebuild based on slot %u of \"%s\"
details.formatString: starting miki-rebuild based on slot %u of \"%s\"

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The tower has finished a miki-rebuild of distributed RAID-1 [parentName]. Any needed mini-rebuilds can now start, followed by midi and maxi rebuilds and I/O resumption. The miki-rebuild copied over [blockCount] blocks.

details.customerDescription: done miki-rebuild based on slot %u of \"%s\" - %u blocks
details.formatString: done miki-rebuild based on slot %u of \"%s\" - %u blocks

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: When attempting to start a needed miki-rebuild of [parentName], it is found that parent is currently not I/O-able. The miki-rebuild cannot proceed, and the Amf will remain suspended.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: \"%s\" is not I
details.internalDescription: When attempting to start a needed miki-rebuild of Distributed RAID-1, it is found that parent is currently not I/O-able.
details.formatString: \"%s\" is not I

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The tower could not allocate buffer space, etc. in order to perform a needed miki-rebuild of device [parentName]. The device will stay suspended.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: Can't get memory to do miki-rebuild of %s
details.internalDescription: The firwmare could not allocate buffer space in order to perform a needed miki-rebuild of Distributed RAID-1.
details.formatString: Can't get memory to do miki-rebuild of %s

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: When attempting to start a needed miki-rebuild of [parentName], it is found that [childName] is currently not I/O-able. The miki-rebuild cannot proceed, and the Amf will remain suspended.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: child \"%s\" of \"%s\" is not I
details.internalDescription: The firwmare could not allocate buffer space in order to perform a needed miki-rebuild of Distributed RAID-1.
details.formatString: child \"%s\" of \"%s\" is not I

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The tower has abandoned a miki-rebuild of distributed RAID-1 [parentName]. This has happened because a change in the set of directors in the system has occurred. The miki-rebuild will be restarted as soon as the new set of directors has stabilized (should be within a second or two).

details.customerDescription: abandoned miki-rebuild based on slot %u of \"%s\" after %u blocks
details.formatString: abandoned miki-rebuild based on slot %u of \"%s\" after %u blocks

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: As a result of a miki-rebuild failing (e.g. storage volumes not reachable), the miki-rebuild code is marking the local child of the distributed RAID-1 as out of date. This sounds strange, since the local child is the data source for the miki-rebuild, but it makes sense. A miki rebuild is designed to make a set of "winning" clusters consistent. The data from the detached cluster does not have to be saved, since the admin has declared that cluster as detached. So, if this director wanted to do a miki-rebuild to bring other clusters in sync with its cluster, and can't, it is OK to simply mark this cluster as out-of-date, even though it might have a few of the blocks from the detached writer that other clusters don't.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Take corrective action, if necessary, to reconnect any disconnected devices. Contact EMC Customer Support for assistance.

details.customerDescription: Marking child \"%s\" of \"%s\" out-of-date
details.internalDescription: A miki-rebuild has failed. (The reason will already have been identified in a separate event.) In order to restore access while minimizing data inconsistency, the local child of the distributed RAID-1 has been marked as out of date and weill be completely rebuilt when possible.
details.formatString: Marking child \"%s\" of \"%s\" out-of-date

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The request to detach the clone [cloneName] (i.e., command "amf removeclone [cloneName]") has been abandoned because a group change has occurred before the request could complete. A group change is when a director joins or leaves the group of running directors. This event is issued on the master amg director only.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Once the system has stabilized, so that directors are neither departing nor arriving, re-issue the request to detach the mirror.

details.customerDescription: Attempt to detach mirror \"%s\" cancelled
details.internalDescription: While the system was processing a detach mirror command, a director either booted up or shut down. To preserve system integrity, all in-process requests to detach mirrors are cancelled when this happens.
details.formatString: Attempt to detach mirror \"%s\" cancelled

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The mirror number [mirrorNum] of device [parentName] could not be removed because a group change has occurred before the request could complete. A group change is when a director joins or leaves the group of running directors. This event is issued on the master amg director only.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Once the system has stabilized, so that directors are neither departing nor arriving, re-issue the request to remove the mirror.

details.customerDescription: Attempt to remove mirror %u of device \"%s\" cancelled
details.internalDescription: While the system was attempting to remove a mirror, a director either booted up or shut down. To preserve system integrity, all in-process requests to remove mirrors are cancelled when this happens.
details.formatString: Attempt to remove mirror %u of device \"%s\" cancelled

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: A storage volume has been provisioned to this cluster, even though the storage volume logically belongs to another cluster. This message likely indicates a back-end zoning or masking problem, because a storage volume should be provisioned to only one cluster.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: A storage volume has been provisioned to this cluster, even though the storage volume logically belongs to another cluster. This message likely indicates a back-end zoning or masking problem, because a storage volume should be provisioned to only one cluster.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Reconfigure the zoning and/or masking on the back-end so that each cluster can see only its local storage volumes. Run the 'array rediscover' command to remove the remote storage volumes.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: Reconfigure the zoning and/or masking on the back-end so that each cluster can see only its local storage volumes. Run the 'array rediscover' command to remove the remote storage volumes.

details.customerDescription: Hiding a storage volume on this cluster as it is claimed by the other cluster.
details.internalDescription: Hiding a storage volume on this cluster as it is claimed by the other cluster.
details.formatString: cluster %u hiding pseudo-remote storage volume %s from cluster %u

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: A log volume is not available (e.g. it might be suspended because of a failure recovery) when we need to write to the log because of a write to the indicated distributed RAID-1 that is coming from a mini-rebuild of that device. To avoid a deadlock in this rare case, we fail the log update, which will cause the local RAID-1 child to be marked as fully out of date.

details.customerDescription: failing dist RAID-1 logging during mini-rebuild of \"%s\"
details.formatString: failing dist RAID-1 logging during mini-rebuild of \"%s\"

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: If seen after startup, the metadata amf specified will have the amfs created from the headers that are stored on it. If seen after transferring metadata, metadata amf [amfName] now has all the amf headers stored on it.

details.customerDescription: Metadata amf \"%s\" successfully activated
details.internalDescription: If seen shortly after startup, this amf has been chosen as the active metadata volume. If seen shortly after transferring metadata to a new volume, then the metadata info has been written to the specified volume. This may have been done in response to a failure on the previously- used metadata volume, or a planned move of the metadata to a new volume.
details.formatString: Metadata amf \"%s\" successfully activated

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: The currently active metadata amf has become unhealthy and it has one or more of the AMF_DEADNESS_FLAGS set.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: The active meta-volume has become unhealthy and is at risk. It is in cache only, and needs to be written to storage volume.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Either resurrect or fix the failed metadata amf, or transfer the metadata to another healthy metadata amf using the command "amf movemeta".
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRemedy: The active meta-volume has become unhealthy. Create another meta-volume using meta-volume create as soon as possible, and then run the meta-volume move command to save the cache data to the newly created meta-volume. Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: Active metadata device or storage volume is not healthy.
details.internalDescription: Active metadata device or storage volume is not healthy.
details.formatString: Active metadata device or storage volume %s is not healthy

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: This is an escape hole for mikis. A cluster that is detached still has elements on its miki queues. We don't have undo miki rebuilds at the moment, so we're forced to mark that cluster's mirror as fully out of date.

details.customerDescription: Stale miki info on detached cluster %u forcing child \"%s\" of dr1 \"%s\" to be marked out of date
details.internalDescription: The mirror of the specified device has been marked as fully out of date in order to resolve some internal block differences. This can happen in an unstable network, in combination with cluster detaches.
details.formatString: Stale miki info on detached cluster %u forcing child \"%s\" of dr1 \"%s\" to be marked out of date

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: All distributed rebuilds are killed and restarted during cluster group changes. This event simply matches the rebuild-started message in that case.

details.customerDescription: raid 1 rebuild: %s: child node %u (%s) rebuild killed (%s rebuild)
details.internalDescription: The rebuild has stopped because of the arrival or departure of a cluster. If it can be restarted after the handling of the cluster event, it will be.
details.formatString: raid 1 rebuild: %s: child node %u (%s) rebuild killed (%s rebuild)

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: We're likely running out of memory, and failed a timer alloc. We'll probably see other bad symptoms shortly after this one.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Contact EMC Customer Support.

details.customerDescription: Failed to allocate timer for %s setting on device or storage volume \"%s\", doing the detach now (instead of waiting %u seconds).
details.internalDescription: The system attempted to allocate a timer to wait for a configured number of seconds before taking action on a detach setting for the specified device. This allocation failed, however, so the action was taken immediately.
details.formatString: Failed to allocate timer for %s setting on device or storage volume \"%s\", doing the detach now (instead of waiting %u seconds).

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: Occurs after an "amf setloser" or "amf setmajority" setting fires. Cached data will be discarded - this is I/O from the host, which YY previously acknowledged, but which was never written to storage volume. Or, if it made it to storage volume temporarily, until the link came back and we realized this cluster is a loser, and then the data gets overwritten by data from the winning cluster(s).
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: Restore communication link or remote cluster.

details.customerDescription: %s setting marked cluster %u detached wrt device or storage volume \"%s\".
details.internalDescription: A detach setting has expired, leading to the detaching of the specified cluster from the specified device. If all missing clusters have been detached, then I/O can resume at the remaining clusters.
details.formatString: %s setting marked cluster %u detached wrt device or storage volume \"%s\".

eventRCAandRemedy.internalRCA: Memory and buffer space to do a sparse rebuild could not be allocated, so we've had to mark a child of a DR1 as fully out-of-date instead.
eventRCAandRemedy.customerRCA: A memory shortage has prevented VPLEX from performing a log-based rebuild to correct a small set of child differences. Because of that, the child will be marked as being completely out-of-date so that it can be rebuilt later, while allowing I/O to continue at present.
eventRCAandRemedy.internalRemedy: Contact EMC Customer Support.
